head.title: Is a Woman's Right to Choose in Jeopardy?

hedline.hl1: Is a Woman's Right to Choose in Jeopardy?

abstract.p: Feminists for Life pres Rosemary O Bottcher letter contends that Oct 26 editorial assumes without proof that Dr Barnett A Slepian was killed by 'anti-choice fanatic'; maintains that it is wrong to blame pro-life movement for violent act of one person

block.p: Your Oct. 26 editorial ''Violence Against Abortion Doctors'' assumes, without proof, that Dr. Barnett A. Slepian was killed by an ''anti-choice fanatic.'' Most likely, the crime was indeed committed by a person opposed to abortion, but it is wrong to blame the pro-life movement for the violent act of one person. Is the environmental movement responsible for the acts of the Unabomber?

Your Oct. 26 editorial ''Violence Against Abortion Doctors'' assumes, without proof, that Dr. Barnett A. Slepian was killed by an ''anti-choice fanatic.'' Most likely, the crime was indeed committed by a person opposed to abortion, but it is wrong to blame the pro-life movement for the violent act of one person. Is the environmental movement responsible for the acts of the Unabomber?

Perhaps the killer was driven to desperation by the rigid refusal of the pro-choice advocates to give an inch on such issues as a ban on partial-birth abortions, waiting periods and parental notification -- despite the fact that these limitations are supported by a wide majority of Americans.
Those of us who are genuinely pro-life are saddened by Dr. Slepian's death. By all accounts, he was a decent man with whom we disagreed.

Strategically, his death is a catastrophe for the pro-life movement because it distracts from our message and galvanizes pro-abortion activists. If the killer thought he could stop abortion by stopping Dr. Slepian, he is not only violent, he is stupid.
ROSEMARY O. BOTTCHER Tallahassee, Fla., Oct. 29, 1998
The writer is president, Feminists for Life.
